quiz.title: Algebra 2: Unit 12 Quiz 5
quiz.subtitle: 12.5: Product-to-Sum and Sum-to-Product Formulas
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Converting between products and sums of trig functions

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct Product-to-Sum identity for $\cos A \cos B$?
questions.explanation: The product of two cosines transforms into the average of the cosines of the difference and the sum of the angles.

questions.question: Express the product $\sin(5x) \cos(3x)$ as a sum or difference.
questions.explanation: Using $\sin A \cos B = \frac{1}{2}[\sin(A + B) + \sin(A - B)]$ with $A=5x$ and $B=3x$ gives $\frac{1}{2}[\sin(8x) + \sin(2x)]$.

questions.question: Simplify the sum $\sin(40^{\circ}) + \sin(20^{\circ})$ using a Sum-to-Product formula.
What is the exact value of $2 \sin(52.5^{\circ}) \sin(7.5^{\circ})$?
Convert the difference $\cos(3\theta) - \cos(\theta)$ to a product.
The expression $\cos(75^{\circ}) + \cos(15^{\circ})$ is equivalent to which product?
Which formula is most helpful for integrating the product of two different sine waves in calculus?
questions.explanation: Product-to-Sum formulas break down complex products into simple additions/subtractions, which are much easier to integrate.

questions.question: Simplify: $\frac{\sin(3x) - \sin(x)}{\cos(3x) + \cos(x)}$.
questions.explanation: Applying Sum-to-Product formulas: $[2 \cos(2x) \sin(x)] / [2 \cos(2x) \cos(x)] = \sin x / \cos x = \tan x$.

questions.question: Product-to-Sum formulas are derived primarily from which other set of identities?
questions.explanation: By adding or subtracting the expansions of $\sin(A \pm B)$ or $\cos(A \pm B)$, we derive the Product-to-Sum identities.

questions.question: Simplify $\cos(x) \sin(x)$ using a Product-to-Sum formula.
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: The Product-to-Sum formula gives $\frac{1}{2}[\sin(x+x) + \sin(x-x)] = \frac{1}{2}[\sin(2x) + 0]$, which is also the double-angle sine formula rearranged.

scoreMessages.90: Masterful! You can shift between sums and products with ease.
scoreMessages.70: Great work. Watch the negative signs in the cosine difference formulas.
scoreMessages.50: Practice the 'average' and 'half-difference' steps in these conversions.
scoreMessages.0: Review the formulas; they are complex but follow a specific symmetry!
